reviewText: The stage and backdrop of "The Show" are pretty spectacular, with a spacious orchestra pit, to boot. I have mixed feelings about this video overall. Damian McGinty was only about 14 years old in this performance, but his voice and his showmanship were unbelievable. He had the skill and poise of a veteran performer. And Paul Byrom's soaring tenor voice was showcased on this DVD; what an incredible voice.But I think that the performance time given to the singers was disproportionate, with McGinty and Byrom being in the spotlight considerably more than the other guys.I have the Heritage DVD also, and it is by far my favorite of the two. Although the set is much, much smaller and less extravagant than The Show's, the sound and picture quality of Heritage is far better (on my TV anyway), and that's what matters to me.Another reason I favor Heritage over The Show is that the audience in The Show  seemed almost lifeless at times, whereas it was just the opposite with Heritage.

reviewText: WOW what a show.  Every once in a while something comes along that is far above everything else. "Celtic Thunder" is just one of those. The show on TV hadn't even finished and I was on the internet looking where I could get this. There are some on this DVD that I didn't like, like Young Love and Desperado. But when Damian sang "Come By The Hills" and George sang "The Old Man" they more than made up for the ones I didn't care for. There was one review that said something about lip sync singing. I think he forgot this was done before a live audience. So so much for lip singing. If you like traditionial celtic and some modern singing this is the DVD for you. I highly recommend it. As for the CD, forget it. It only has 15 of the 28 songs on the DVD. I think the CD is a ripoff.

reviewText: What a great DVD for anyone that loves fine male voices - and great backup musicians, too.  I've listened to Celtic Thunder before but this is the first time I had ever seen them performing."A Bird Without Wings" sang by young Damien McGinty and accompanied by George Donaldson was heartstopping (I'm thinking it would be a perfect song for my youngest son's wedding one day).  I had never heard the song before - loved it (can you tell?).I also really liked "Caledonia", "The Old Man", "Heartland", gorgeous version of "Nights in White Satin", "My Boy", and "Ireland's Call", although there wasn't even one song that I didn't enjoy listening to.  A big portion of my ancestry is Irish and it seemed I felt these songs (at least the Celtic ones) calling to something inside me.  I felt the same thing the first time I saw Celtic Woman sing inCeltic Woman: A New Journey--Live at Slane Castle.  We are truly blessed to have such talent available for us to enjoy.

reviewText: If you want to see the first Celtic Thunder show and from where they all started--here it is! Excellent show! There are 28 songs which range from being just familiar, popular, and cute to very dramatic. No one would be disappointed in this DVD. The stage is fantastic. The harmony of the varied voices of the five talented men is superb. Love hearing them sing as an ensemble. As individuals, George, having lost his own father, brings true feeling to "The Old Man." Damian owns the song "A Bird Without Wings," but George adds the right touch in singing backup to this song. Charismatic Ryan does an outstanding job with "Brothers in Arms" and anything he sings. Paul's voice is unbelievably pure--it shines! Keith sings a song he wrote, "Lauren & I." The orchestra is just fantastic. Love the drums! Phil Coulter has done a wonderful job as musical director and in composing some great songs. This is a complete, entertaining package! Love the kilts!

reviewText: Another British invasion? "Celtic Thunder" is a group of 5 men from Ireland and Scotland, whose voices are truly amazing. Each has a strong and distinctive solo voice, but also blend well when they sing together. The music isn't all Celtic in nature - "Desperado" "That's a Woman" and "Puppy Love" are among those that aren't. The show is about 2 hours, and when they're finished, you'll find yourself wanting more! They are engaging performers who immediately connect with their audience. It would be difficult to choose a favorite - each having a unique style. This is not a "boy band." It is a DVD you'll watch again and again! My only disappointment is that the CD only has about half the songs from the DVD. I wish they had made it a double CD set. I am hoping they will make another recording soon. If you like Celtic music at all ... even if only on St. Patrick's Day, this is a DVD you will enjoy!

reviewText: If this style of romantic Irish music is your thing, you will probably love this concert.  However I was disappointed because the ENTIRE thing looks lip synched.  Having worked in live performance my entire life, I understand the difficulties of live audio production especially in a large space.  The audio on this DVD sounds extremely over produced, too perfect, too slick, especially since they are using lavalier mics.  You never hear the singers even take in a breath or a uneven level of sound no matter how high or low the pitch which is a sure sign of studio production and not a LIVE performance.  The other sign that it is not being performed live is that all of the performers don't all do a great job of matching their lips to the words. And when a singer is singing live you can see it their diaphragm, their body will move, some of the singers make this look believable whereas others look completely fake.  The worst offender being the young Damian McGinty. He doesn't even come close to matching the audio.  I really hope that they perform LIVE when in concert and that they only lip synched for this PBS broadcast.  Again I don't know 100% that they are lip synching but it looks extremely suspicious that they are not singing live.  It ruined the whole show for me.  They are obviously talented performers.  Go to a live theater show, and see for yourself, the singing doesn't sound like this, you can hear the tiny imperfections, proof that it is LIVE SINGING!
summary: The whole thing looks like it was lip synched

reviewText: Celtic Thunder are just sensational and I haven't seen the complete DVD yet. They are so good that I had to write a review to let the whole world know that they are on the verge of greatness. The presentation is superb with the Celtic Concert Orchestra conducted by that wonderful arranger Phil Coulter. There are at least two stars in the making - Damian McGinty (15 yrears old) and Keith Harkin (21 years old) whose renditions of songs are fantastic. There is a mix of traditional irish music and modern numbers, two of which were written by Phil Coulter. The Orchestra and other musicians are superb - I can't wait for their next DVD.

reviewText: I,like many others, found them on my PBS station last year during their fund raising.  Had to get it immediately & Amazon had it.  Purchased the CD & their Christmas one also.  Told my Aunt "If I was 30 yrs younger I could flip over Damian".  Then I got it for her for last Christmas as she has been to Ireland many times visiting a dear friend of hers & thought it would bring back wonderful memories----it did.  Now I've just told my Nephew about them & going to send it to him.  In June PBS was doing another fund raiser---THEIR COMING IN NOVEMBER TO SACRAMENTO.  Pledged the most ever----got 4 tickets--for me, 2 grandsons & daughter to see them.  Can hardly wait & I wonder what the show will be.  Hoping they have a DVD for sale there so I can add to my collection.  I love to put it in, turn the volume up; the music, the orchestra--drums I never saw & played differently, the songs, ones I never heard before but now love.  When you watch it you feel like your there & want to start claping too.  Can't say enough about them other than----FANTASTIC!!!!

reviewText: This was the first show I saw of Celtic Thunder, having only discovered them a few months ago, and at the time I thought it was quite good. Now, having seen what they really can do when the right people come together ( see Mythology, and the Voyage shows), I find this first show very far from satisfying. All the traditional Irish songs were great and well performed, but I always have to skip the parts where Paul Byrom howls at the moon, and I cringe when I hear Damian's "cutesy" songs like Puppy Love. A celtic show could also do without oldies like Desperado, or boring droning songs like Steal away ( please, leave that for Tommy Fleming!). On the other hand, Mountains of Mourne, Lauren and I, Brothers in arms and especially The Island, those are songs I can listen to over and over again. I'm glad the show has evolved to allow the artists to showcase their own creations, and that they replaced Damian and Paul.

reviewText: My goodness, what a buy. Lots of good music and singing. I bought this one the same time I bought the new one, Heritage. Some of these songs are just so good. I love "Come by the Hills" that Damian does. In this one, he sings part of it in English, and does a great job, even though he was quite young at the time. He also does "A Bird Without Wings." another very nice song. Later, he sings a couple of old US songs from the fifties or early sixties, (I am not sure, but they are quite cute, and my family got a kick out of them).Keith sings "The Island," which happens to have been the first song I every heard him sing. I was glued to my monitor. What a thought-provoker. He is really a good story teller. "Lauren & I" is a song he wrote, and it is quite engaging. His other solo is "I Want to Know what Love Is." David Phelps (a marvelous singer) does the same song, ~and they are so different in their presentation that one would scarcely notice that it is the same song. I like them both, but for the type of song this is, Keith makes it sound more personal. He has that low,soft presentation that sounds like he's thinking, and for this song, it really works. (This is a big statement for me, because I love David's singing.)Ryan is a kick. He makes me smile. Those girls that help him and Paul do numbers are great, because I should laugh aloud, for sure. He can also be very serious. He is fun to watch when he is flirting or whatever, and rather fascinating when he is dramatic. I really like him.You must hear Paul sing Knights in White Satin. Very pretty. Paul has a most well-trained voice. Another pleasure to hear is, "Love Thee Dearest." I enjoy him on all his songs. There is no reason not to; he has a great voice.George is another good story-teller. Oh, they all are -but Keith and George tell the touchy feely ones; Ryan's are usually more dramatic, whether romantic or about some dramatic event. George has a nice rather deep voice and a solid presence. He, like the other Irishmen has a twinkle in his eyes and an engaging expression that seems about to give birth to a secret. His solos are slices of life for the most part. I find Damian and Keith to be the more solemn ones, when they are serious. Ryan and George, even when serious, look like they might smile at any moment, and Paul has a cute way of flirting with the program, and sometimes he too looks like he is about to surprise somebody.I believe you would enjoy this DVD. There are twenty-eight (28) songs; you would just about have to like some of them! Again, I say:  What a buy!Mickey Thorne / Portland USA

reviewText: I would have to agree with the reviewer who said that they should be called Celtic Breeze instead; Heartland, the first song, is the only really "thunderous" track.  These guys are extremely talented, and have a nice eye candy factor, too.  Paul especially has a gorgeous tenor voice.  Just like Celtic Woman, songs range from pop to semi-classical to folk, although I would say the concert has more pop than anything.  They sing so well that even the cheesy choreography and over-produced set don't ruin their performances.  Heartland, however, is performed eerily like Stonehenge from This is Spinal Tap (check it out on Youtube to see what I mean).  As much as I enjoy this concert, I would have to say that I've enjoyed The High Kings dvd I bought much more, as they play more traditional music.
summary: Not very thunderous, but still good.

reviewText: I have a hard time taking reviews of CDs or DVDs seriously if they only talk about how much the buyer loved or hated the performance. To me that is 100% subject to individual taste.  I may love Josh Grobin, All American Rejects, Coldplay, The Verve, etc. and you may hate them all or any one of them.  No problem. So I'll limit talking about my own personal musical tastes in writing this review.My first exposure to Celtic Thunder was some late-night TV commercial enticing me to buy their DVD online. I am not for or against Celtic music but honestly have never bought any. I liked the short blurb I saw about this DVD so I searched Amazon and found there was a DVD version under $15 bucks so I bought it. The shipping point was in my home town, so even though I bought it late Sunday night I received it early Tuesday with no tax and no shipping charges. Woohoo, thank you Amazon!We played about half the DVD the first night. YOU decide if you love them or hate them musically but my review is that the video quality is one of the best I have seen ... very close to Blu-Ray quality on a normal DVD player. The editing is expert ... clean, logical and unobtrusive. The audio is first-rate, very transparent and clean, it took full advantage of my Amazon-purchased amplifier and speakers.For under fifteen bucks, it is hard to imagine a DVD that will bring you more entertainment. Ok, maybe Celtic music isn't for everybody but these performers are way too wide ranged to be considered only "Celtic". There are a couple of songs that truly brought tears to my eyes, and one or two (like Damien singing Puppy Love) that were so infectious that even the studio musicians on the DVD were so overtaken by smiles that they almost lost place playing their instruments.For the price, even if you watch this DVD only once, it is hard to imagine anyone not falling in love with it.PROS:  Good cheap entertainment, great video and soundCONS:  Logical assumption that they would sing together more, it's mostly a series of solosBONUS:  Totally fresh versions of a few very familiar songs. First-class talent.

reviewText: This is a truly mature and heartwarming performance by men who know and respect their music. Right off the bat, I was taken with George. He has manliness without the brovado or stage drama. His approach and sincerity strikes a chord deep within me. Next I had to notice Keith with his lighter, golden voice. He has a lot of honesty and isn't afraid to be vulnerable at times. Very nice in group and individual pieces. Damian of course can't help stealing the show, running to the front on the fast songs, or slowly pacing with tender inflection on songs like "Come By the Hills" and "A Bird Without Wings". Paul and Ryan balance what could have been a vanilla mix with drama and comedy. I really don't like "Heartbreaker", and Ryan also plays the evil jerk in "That's A Woman", but "Ride On" and "Brothers in Arms" are mysterious and exciting, and Paul is very good for some ushy gushy romance. Simply said, this is a very cool show. The only reason I give four stars instead of five is because I can't help thinking it would have been even better if they had decided to lean slightly closer to a traditional blend. "Puppy Love" and kilts just have my eyes crossing. LOL, Celtic Thunder, as you continue to rock our socks off.

reviewText: I watched this on PBS during their recent beg-a-thon.  The voices are superb, the production values are excellent, and I fell in love with the woman in the blue dress who played the cello.  I think those who liked the musical variety shows on television (Lawrence Welk, Andy Williams, Perry Como) will like this very much.  My mother, for example, loved it.  She also likes Celtic Women and Lord of the Dance, and other "pretty" music. It's all very pleasant, if not very exciting. It looks wonderful, however, and the audience appeared to enjoy the show immensely.I don't believe the singers were live, but they did an excellent job of lip-synching. Along that line, I'm not positive that the "live" shots of the audience were truly live.  It may well be that shots were inserted during the editing process (a shot of a young girl with tears streaming down her face during one song seemed suspiciously lucky).As to the complaints that this isn't authentic or traditional Irish music, well, some of it is. It's not the Chieftains, or even Clannad, but it's pretty good pop music.  Anyone who can resist the 14 year old kid singing "Puppy Love" probably should avoid this DVD.If you like this kind of theatrical production, however, and you can go along with the fantasy aspect of the whole thing, you may enjoy the DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I thought I'd gotten old and jaded. I've seen the Beatles live (Forest Hills Stadium, NYC 1964); and the whole gamut from Rick James to Hank, Jr. Video - or live - this is the best concert I've seen in my life. Five magnificent voices, five distinctive styles, carefully melded into a series of individual and group performances. A young teen (Damian McGinty) who will absolutely knock your socks off; Paul Byrom, a genuine Irish Tenor, who's doing his best work in a group format; Ryan Kelly, a young accountant who's living his dream with a killer voice; Keith Harkin a future solo superstar singer, guitarist, and composer who the whole world will hear from soon; and George Donaldson, a Scottish folk singer, who cannot be ignored by the Broadway stage. Phil Coulter and Sharon Brown have created a visually stunning project that grabs you for close to 2 hours and won't let go. Add the super work of whistle & pipe genius, Brendan Monaghan, top-flight guitarist Neil Byrne, bassist, Nigel Wheatley, and percussionists Rory McCarron and Audrey Bridgeman, and it's the greatest concert experience you can have. This ain't the Clancy Brothers and Tommy Makem singing Toora Loora Loora; it's a blend of Celtic and modern in a/v harmony.Don't miss the interviews. You'll meet 5 guys with their feet planted on the ground, especially Damian who says he has "a mommy and a daddy". What an endearing kid!! Attention family members: guess what your Christmas gift will be this year? One you'll remember and thank me for forever!! Buy this DVD!!!
summary: Magnificent, and that's not a strong enough word!!

reviewText: I happened across Celtic Thunder during a PBS member drive (showing Celtic Thunder:  Take Me Home) and was immediately hooked.  Never before has an ensemble kept me as entertained as these guys do.  I have all of their CDs/DVDs (partly because some songs are only included on the CD or DVD exclusively).  Celtic Thunder:  The Show is an earlier production featuring the same artists but has the same quality.  I still find it odd to see the group that young.  However, their talent and blend was not lacking in the least.  I do, however, still enjoy the blend that the ensemble has inTake Me HomeandIt's Entertainment!.  That said, this is an excellent addition to any movie collection especially since it is fun that an entire family can have together.

reviewText: After watching what was allowed on a PBS special, the complete concert is here in all it's glory.Being half Scottish myself, i really enjoyed this concert.Phil Coulter, who was responsible for the popularity of the Bay City Rollers back in the early 70's, assembled 5 men, ages ranging from 14 to probably 35 (a guess). Each man sings very, very well. Has superb stage presence, and also dances. Such a display of talent here is recognized by a devotion to entertain, and each does in abundance.

reviewText: I enjoyed these so much when I saw them on TV that I wanted to see more so I ordered this.  I truly enjoyed this and all of their singing and shows.
